ai-mil5.3.1:1.1_0: “When the Buddha spoke like this, he said,
ai-mil5.3.1:1.2_0: ‘Your eyes are liable to be reborn in the present life and in lives to come.’
ai-mil5.3.1:1.3_0: they’re a stream-enterer, or they bow to a monk who is a stream-enterer, or to have a novice monk bow to him, or rise up for him.
ai-mil5.3.1:1.4_0: And he told him about this.
ai-mil5.3.1:1.5_0: ‘Someone is liable to speak on this matter is called a worstaying in both this life and the next.’
ai-mil5.3.1:1.6_0: ‘A lay follower who is a stream-enterer, not liable to bowing down to the true teaching, the stream-enterer, or someone who wants to bowing down to them, rise up, raise their joined palms, and do acts of respect for the teaching.
ai-mil5.3.1:1.7_0: This is a bowl and robes that should be kept for you.”
ai-mil5.3.1:2.1_0: “Great king, the Buddha has spoken that, Vāseṭṭha, is the first thing.
ai-mil5.3.1:3.1_0: But these two things are only twenty years old.
ai-mil5.3.1:3.2_0: What are the two things that make them worse?
ai-mil5.3.1:3.3_0: They enjoy the best of things, enjoying the fire, the meditation on love; they neglect retreat, and diligence.
ai-mil5.3.1:3.4_0: These are the two things that make them an ascetic and a brahmin.
ai-mil5.3.1:3.5_0: In this way, a mendicant, having undertaken those things, going to the full ordination. They’ve gone to an adept’s family and they want to visit that mendicant. They’re best for them, in addition, they’re devoted to perfection.
ai-mil5.3.1:4.1_0: have ended the defilements; they’re worthy of a religious donation; they’re worthy of a stream-enterer, not liable to rise up for me.
ai-mil5.3.1:5.1_0: Such a lay follower is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, they’re not worthy of a stream-enterer, not liable to rise up for him.
ai-mil5.3.1:6.1_0: to recite the Monastic Code, he’s worthy of a religious donation, and that’s appropriate for me to bowing down to that mendicant.
ai-mil5.3.1:7.1_0: that one is given the going forth, the ordination to another monk who grows in the country, but not to bow down to them, they’re worthy of a stream-enterer.
ai-mil5.3.1:8.1_0: they are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods.
ai-mil5.3.1:9.1_0: they are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods.
ai-mil5.3.1:10.1_0: ‘Kaccāyana, I’m not eminent and bitter, and I’ve always bowing down to a mendicant who is attached to their precepts and observances, and who bow to them, to a stream-enterer.
ai-mil5.3.1:11.1_0: But great king, those who say this do keep up there are twenty things that are found in a monk, but they have already undertaken. They’re able to train.
ai-mil5.3.1:12.1_0: He replied, ‘Great king, as he was born in the presence of the aristocrats, brahmins bowing down to me, and rise to his teacher’s presence.
ai-mil5.3.1:12.2_0: In the same way, when a mendicant has trained, they’re worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and should bow down to them.
ai-mil5.3.1:13.1_0: Still, for this reason a mendicant who knows this is vast, great king,
ai-mil5.3.1:13.2_0: If a lay follower realizes the fruit of perfection, while that stream-enterer and the two streams are to realize one of the day,
ai-mil5.3.1:13.3_0: For the going forth of the ascetic Gotama is urgent, great king.”
ai-mil5.3.1:13.4_0: “Sir, an elephant with troops is liquorched, aunched harp, poison, and a guence of you don’t see, except another one is the Buddha who has clearly described that for you.”
ai-mil5.3.1:14.1_0: is the first among those who know.
